sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That is Laertes a very noble youth.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What Ceremony elſe?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Her obſequies have been as far inlarg'd
As we have warranty; her death was doubtful,
And but that great command o're-ſways the order,
She ſhould in ground unſanctified been lodg'd:
For charitable prayers,
Flints and pebbles ſhould be thrown on her,
Yet here ſhe is allow'd her virgin rites,
Her maiden ſtrewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and burial.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Muſt there no more be done?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No more:
We ſhould profane the ſervice of the dead
To ſing a Requiem and ſuch reſt to her
As to peace-parted ſouls.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Lay her i'th' earth,
And from her fair and unpolluted fleſh
May violets ſpring: I tell thee churliſh Prieſt
A miniſtring Angel ſhall my ſiſter be
When thou lieſt howling.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What? the fair Ophelia?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sweets to the ſweet, farewel,
I hop'd thou ſhould'ſt have been my Hamlet's wife,
I thought thy bride bed to have deckt ſweet maid,
And not have ſtrew'd thy grave.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: O treble woe!
Fall ten times double on that curſed head,
Whoſe wicked deeds deprived thee of
Thy moſt ingenuous ſenſe: hold off the earth a while,
Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
Now pile your duſt upon the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountain you have made
T'oretop old Pelion, or the skyiſh head
Of blew Olympus.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is he whoſe grief
Bears ſuch an emphaſis, whoſe phraſe of ſorrow
Conjures the wandring ſtars, and makes them ſtand
Like wonder-wounded hearers? 'tis I,
Hamlet the Dane.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Perdition catch thee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Thou pray'ſt not well: I prethee take thy fingers from my throat,
For though I am not ſpleenative and raſh,
Yet have I in me ſomething dangerous,
Which let thy wiſdom fear; hold off thy hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pluck them aſunder.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Good my Lord be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: Why I will fight with him upon this theam
Until my eye-lids will no longer wag.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O my ſon, what theam?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I lov'd Ophelia, forty thouſand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of love
Make up my ſum: What wilt thou do for her?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O he is mad Laertes.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Forbear him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Shew me what thou't do,
Wilt weep, wilt fight, wilt faſt, wilt tear thy ſelf,
Wilt drink up Eſil, eat a Crocodile?
I'll do't; doeſt thou come here to whine?
To out-face me with leaping in her grave?
Be buried quick with her, and ſo will I;
And if thou prate of mountains, let them throw
Millions of acres on us, till our ground
Sindging his pate againſt the burning Zone,
Make Oſſa like a wart; nay, and thou'lt mouth
I'll rant as well as thou.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: This is meer madneſs,
And thus a while the fit will work on him;
Anon as patient as a female Doe,
When firſt her golden couplets are diſclos'd,
His ſilence will ſit drooping.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hear you Sir,
What is the reaſon that you uſe me thus?
I lov'd you ever, but it is no matter,
Let Hercules himſelf do what he may
The Cat will mew, a Dog will have his day.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I pray thee good Horatio wait upon him.
Strengthen your patience in our laſt nights ſpeech,
We'll put the matter to the preſent puſh.
Good Gertrard ſet ſome watch over your ſon,
This Grave ſhall have a living monument,
"An hour of quiet thereby ſhall we ſee,
"Till then in patience our proceeding be.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: So much for this Sir you ſhall now ſee the other:
You do remember all the circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Hora
sp.l: Remember it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me ſleep, "methought I lay
"Worſe than the mutines in the Bilboes, raſhly,
"And prais'd be raſhneſs for it; let us know
Our indiſcretion ſometimes ſerves us well
When our deep plots do fall, and that ſhould learn us,
There's a divinity that ſhapes our ends,
Rough hew them how we will.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That is moſt certain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Up from my Cabbin,
My Sea-gown wrapt about me, in the dark
I grop'd to find out them, had my deſire,
Reach'd their packet, and in fine withdrew
To mine own room again, making ſo bold
(My fears forgetting manners to unfold
Their grand Commiſſion, where I found, Horatio,
An exact command,
"Larded with many ſeveral ſorts of reaſons,
"Importing Denmarks health, and Englands too,
"With hoe ſuch Bugs and Goblins in my life,
"That on the ſuperviſe, no leiſure bated,
"No not to ſtay the grinding of the ax,
My head ſhould be ſtrook off.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Is't poſſible;

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here's the Commiſſion, read it at more leaſure:
But wilt thou hear now how I did proceed?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Being thus be-netted round with villains,
E're I could make a Prologue to my brains
They had begun the Play: I ſate me down,
Devis'd a new Commiſſion, wrote it fair:
I once did hold it, as our Statiſts do,
A baſeneſs to write fair, and labour'd much
How to forget that learning; but Sir now
It did me Yeomans ſervice; wilt thou know
Th'effect of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: Hora
sp.l: I good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: An earneſt conjuration from the King,
As England was his faithful tributary,
As love between them like the Palm might flouriſh,
As peace ſhould ſtill her wheaten garland wear,
"And ſtand a Comma 'tween their amities,
"And many ſuch like, as Sir of great charge,
That on the view of theſe contents,
Without debatement further more or leſs
He ſhould thoſe bearers put to ſudden death,
"Not ſhriving time allow'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: How was this ſeal'd?

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.l: Why even in that was heaven ordinant:
I had my fathers Signet in my purſe,
Which was the model of that Daniſh Seal,
Folded the Writ up in the form of th other,
Subſcrib'd it, gav't th' impreſſion, plac'd it ſafely,
The changling never known; now the next day
Was our Sea-fight, and what to this was ſequent
Thou know'ſt already.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: So Guildenſtern and Roſencraus went to't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: They are not near my conſcience, their defeat
Does by their own inſinuation grow;
"'Tis dangerous when the baſer nature comes
"Between the paſs and fell incenſed point.
"Of mighty oppoſites.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why what a King is this!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Does it not, think you, ſtand me now upon?
He that hath kill • d my King, and whor'd my mother,
Stept in between th' election and my hopes,
Thrown out his angle for my proper life,
And with ſuch coſenage, is't not perfect conſcience?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip is right welcome back to Denmark.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I humbly thank you Sir,
Doeſt know this water flie?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Thy ſtate is the more graciou, for 'tis a vice to know him; he hath much land and fertil, let a beaſt be Lord of beaſts, and his crib ſhall ſtand at the Kings meſs; 'tis a chough, but as I ſay, ſpacious in the poſſeſſion of dirt.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sweet Lord, If your Lordſhip were at leiſure I ſhould impart a thing to you from his Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I will receive it, Sir, with all diligence of ſpirit; your bonnet to his right uſe, 'tis for the head.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I thank your Lordſhip, 'tis very hot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No believe me 'tis very cold, the wind is Northerly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: It is indifferent cold my Lord indeed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: But yet me thinks it is very foultry and hot, for my complexion.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Exceedingly my Lord, it is very ſoultry, as 'twere I cannot tell how. My Lord, his Majeſty bad me ſignifie unto you, that he has laid a great wager on your head, Sir this is the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I beſeech you remember.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord, for my eaſe. Sir here is newly come to Court Laertes, believe me an abſolute Gentleman, full of moſt excellent differences, of very ſoft ſociety, and great ſhew: indeed, to ſpeak feelingly of him, he is the Card or Kalendar of Gentry, for you ſhall find in him the ſubſtance of what part a Gentleman would ſee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Sir, his definement ſuffers no loſs in you, though I know to divide him inventorially, would dizzy th' arithmetick of memory, and yet but raw neither in reſpect of his quick ſail; but in the verity of extolment I take him to be a ſoul of great article, and his infuſion of ſuch dearth and rareneſs, as to make true diction of him, his ſemblable is his mirrour, and who elſe would trace him, his umbrage, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip ſpeaks moſt infallibly of him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: The concernancy Sir, why do we wrap the Gentleman in our rawer breath?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Is't not poſſible to underſtand in another tongue, you will do't Sir really

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What imports the nomination of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Of Laertes?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: His purſe is empty already, all's golden words are ſpert.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.p: Of him Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: I know you are not ignorant.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I would you did Sir, yet if you did it would not much approve me: well Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You are ignorant of what excellence Laertes is.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I dare not confeſs that, leſt I ſhould compare with him in excellence; but to know a man well were to know himſelf.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I mean Sir for his weapon, but in the imputation laid on him by them in his meed he's unfellowed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What's his weapon?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Single Rapier.

The King Sir hath wager'd with him ſix Barbery horſes, againſt the which he has impawn'd as I take it ſix French Rapiers and Poniards, with their aſſigns, as Girdle, Hanger, and ſo: three of the carriages are very dear to fancy, very reſponſive to the hilts, moſt delicate carriages and of very liberal conceit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What call you the carriages?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I knew you muſt be edified by the margin e're you had done.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The carriages Sir are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: The phraſe would be more german to the matter if we could carry a cannon by our ſides, I would it might be hangers till then: but on, ſix Barbary horſes againſt ſix French ſwords, their aſſigns, and three liberal conceited carriages, that's the French bet againſt the Daniſh, why is this all you call it?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The King Sir, hath laid Sir, that in a dozen paſſes between your ſelf and him he ſhall not exceed you three hits, he hath laid on twelve for nine, and it would come to immediate trial, if your Lordſhip would vouchſafe the anſwer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How if I anſwer no?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I mean my Lord the oppoſition of your perſon in trial.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Sir I will walk here in the Hall, if it pleaſe his Majeſty, it is the breathing time of the day with me, let the ſoils be brought, the Gentleman willing, and the King hold his purpoſe, I will win for him if I can; if not, I will gain nothing but my ſhame and the odd hits.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Shall I deliver you ſo?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: To this effect Sir, after what flouriſh your nature will.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I commend my duty to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Yours does well to commend it ſelf, there are no tongues elſe for his turn.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: This lapwing runs away with the ſhell on his head.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: " He did ſo Sir with his dug before he ſucht it; thus has he and many more of the ſame breed that I know, the droſſie age dotes on, only get the tune of the time, and out of an habit of incounter, a kind of miſty collection, which carries them through and through the moſt profane and renowned opinions, and do but blow them to their trial, the bubbles are out.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My Lord, his Majeſty commended him to you by young Oſtrick who brings back to him that you attend him in the hall, he ſends to know if your pleaſure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will take longer time?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I am conſtant to my purpoſes, they follow the Kings pleaſure; if his fitneſs ſpeaks, mine is ready, now or whenſoever, provided I be ſo able as now.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The King and Queen and all are coming down.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: In happy time.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The Queen deſires you to uſe ſome gentle entertainment to Laertes before you go to play.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: She well inſtructs me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: You will loſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I do not think ſo, ſince he went into France I have been in continual practice; I ſhall win at the odds: thou wouldeſt not think how ill all's here about my heart, but it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: It is but foolery, but it is ſuch a kind of boding as would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: If your mind diſlike any thing obey it, I will foreſtal their repair hither, and ſay you are not fit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Not a whit, we defie Augury, there is a ſpecial providence in the fall of a Sparrow: if it be, 'tis not to come; if it be not to come, it will be now; if it be not now, yet it will come, the readineſs is all, ſince no man of ought he leaves knows what 'tis to leave betimes, let be.
sp.stage: A Table prepared, Drums, Trumpets, and Officers with cuſhions, King, Queen, and all the State, Foils, Daggers, and Laertes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Give me your pardon Sir, I have done you wrong,
But pardon't as you are a Gentleman: this preſence knows,
And you muſt needs have heard how I am puniſht
With a ſore diſtraction; what I have done
That might your nature, honour, and exception
Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madneſs.
Was't Hamlet wrong'd Laertes? never Hamlet;
If Hamlet from himſelf be ta'en away,
And when he's not himſelf does wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it:
Who does it then? his madneſs: if't be ſo,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged,
His madneſs is poor Hamlet's enemy;
Let my diſclaiming from a purpos'd evil
Free me ſo far in your moſt generous thoughts,
That I have ſhot my arrow o're the houſe,
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied in nature,
Whoſe motive in this caſe ſhould ſtir me moſt
To my revenge, "but in my terms of honour
"I ſtand aloof, and will no reconcilement,
"Till by ſome elder Maſters of known honour
"I have a voice and preſident of peace
"To my name ungor'd: but all that time''
I do receive your offered love like love,
And will not wrong it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I embrace it freely, and will this brothers wager
Frankly play.
Give us the foils.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come, one for me.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: I'll be your foil Laertes, in mine ignorance
Your skill ſhall like a ſtar i'th darkeſt night
Appear.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: You mock me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No on my honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give them the foils young Oſtrick: couſin Hamlet,
You know the wager.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Very well my Lord:
Your Grace has laid the odds o'th weaker ſide.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do not fear it, I have ſeen you both,
But ſince he is better we have therefore odds.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This is too heavy, let me ſee another.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: This likes me well, theſe foils have all a length.

sp.speaker: Oſtr
sp.l: I my good Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Set me the ſtoops of wine upon the table;
If Hamlet give the firſt or ſecond hit,
Or quit in anſwer of the third exchange,
Let all the Battlements their Ordnance fire;
The King ſhall drink to Hamlet's better breath,
And in the cup an Onyx ſhall he throw
Richer than that which four ſucceſſive Kings
In Denmarks Crown have worn. Give me the cups,
And let the Kettle to the Trumpet ſpeak,
The Trumpet to the Cannoneer without,
The Cannons to the Heavens the Heavens to Earth.
Now the King drinks to Hamlet: come begin,
And you the Judges bear a wary eye.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come on Sir.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: One.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Judgment.

sp.speaker: Oſtr.
sp.l: A hit, a very palpable hit.
sp.stage: [Drums, Trumpets, and Shot, Flouriſh, a Piece goes off.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Well again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, give me drink, Hamlet this pearl is thine,
Here's to thy health: give him the cup.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I'll play this bout firſt, ſet it by a while.
Come, another hit, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I do confeſs't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our ſon ſhall win.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He's fat and ſcant of breath.
Here Hamlet, take my Handkerchief, wipe thy brows:
The Queen ſalutes thy fortune Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good Madam.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gertrard do not drink.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I will my Lord, I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is the poiſoned cup, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I dare not drink yet Madam, by and by.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My Lord I'll hit him now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do not think't.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And yet it is almoſt againſt my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come, for the third Laertes, you do but dally,
I pray you paſs with your beſt violence,
I am ſure you make a wanton of me.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Say you ſo? come on.

sp.speaker: Oſtr.
sp.l: Nothing neither way.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Have at you now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Part them, they are incens't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay come again.

sp.speaker: Oſtr.
sp.l: Look to the Queen there ho.

sp.speaker: Hora
sp.l: They bleed on both ſides, how is't my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oſtr.
sp.l: How is't Laertes?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why as a Woodcock in mine own ſprindge Oſtrick,
I am juſtly kill'd with mine own treachery.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How does the Queen?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She ſwoons to ſee them bleed.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No no the drink, the drink, O my dear Hamlet,
The drink, the drink, I am poiſoned.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O villain! ho let the door be lockt,
Treachery, ſeek it out.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: It is here Hamlet; thou art ſlain,
No medicine in the world can do thee good,
In thee there is not half an hours life,
The treacherous inſtrument is in my hand,
Unbated and envenom'd, the foul practice
Hath turn'd it ſelf on me; ſo here I lie
Never to riſe again: thy mothers poiſon'd,
I can no more, the King, the King's to blame.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The point envenom • d too, then venom to thy work.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treaſon, treaſon,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O yet defend me friends, I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here thou inceſtuous Dane,
"Drink off this potion: is the Onyx here?
Follow my mother.

sp.speaker: Laert.
sp.l: "He is juſtly ſerv'd, it is a poiſon temper'd by himſelf.
Exchange forgiveneſs with me noble Hamlet,
Mine and my fathers death come not upon thee,
Nor thine on me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heaven make thee free of it, I follow thee:
I am dead Horatio, wretched Queen farewel.
You that look pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes or audience to this act,
Had I but time (as this fell Sergeant Death
Is ſtrict in his arreſt) O I could tell you;
But let it be: Horatio I am dead,
Thou liveſt, report me and my cauſe aright
To the unſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Never believe it.
I am more an antick Roman than a Dane,
Here's yet ſome liquor left.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As th'art a man
Give me the cup, let go, I'll have't:
O Horatio what a wounded name,
Things ſtanding thus unknown, ſhall I leave behind me?
If thou didſt ever hold me in thy heart
Abſent thee from felicity a while,
And in this harſh world draw thy breath in pain
To tell my ſtory: what warlike noiſe is this?

sp.speaker: Oſtr.
sp.l: Young Fortinbraſs with conqueſt from Poland,
Th' Embaſſadors of England give this warlike volley.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O I die Horatio,
The potent poiſon quite o'regrows my ſpirit;
I cannot live to hear the news from England,
But I do propheſie the election lights
On Fortinbraſs; he has my dying voice,
So tell him, with th' occurrents more and leſs
Which have ſolicited: the reſt in ſilence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Now cracks a noble heart, good night ſweet Prince,
And choires of Angels ſing thee to thy reſt.
Why does the drum come hither?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Where is this ſight?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What is it you would ſee?
If ought of woe or wonder, ceaſe your ſearch?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: "This quarry cries on havock:'' O proud death,
What feaſt is toward in thine infernal Cell,
That thou ſo many Princes at a ſhot
So bloodily haſt ſtrook?

sp.speaker: Embaſſ.
sp.l: The ſight is diſmal,
And our affairs from England come too late,
The ears are ſenſleſs that ſhould give us hearing
To tell him his commandment is fulfill'd,
That Roſencraus and Guildenſtern are dead,
Where ſhould we have our thanks?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not from his mouth,
Had it th' ability of breath to thank you
He never gave commandement for their death.
But ſince ſo apt upon this bloody queſtion
You from the Pollack wars, and you from England
Are here arrived, give order that theſe bodies
High on a ſtage be placed to publick view,
And let me ſpeak to th' yet unknowing world
How theſe things came about; ſo ſhall you hear
Of cruel, bloody, and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgments, caſual ſlaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning, and for no cauſe,
And in this upſhot, purpoſes miſtook,
Fall'n on the inventors heads: all this can I
Truly deliver.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Let us haſte to hear it,
And call the nobleſs to the audience:
For me, with ſorrow I embrace my fortune,
I have ſome rights of memory in this Kingdom,
Which now to claim my intereſt doth invite me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Of that I ſhall have alſo cauſe to ſpeak,
And from his mouth whoſe voice will draw no more:
But let this ſame be preſently perform'd,
Even while mens minds are wild, leſt more miſchance
On plots and errors happen.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: " Let four Captains
Bear Hamlet like a Souldier to the Stage,
For he was likely had he been put on,
T'have prov'd moſt royal: and for his paſſage,
The Souldiers Muſick and the rights of War
Speak loudly for him.
Take up the bodies; ſuch a ſight as this
Becomes the Field, but here ſhews much amiſs
" Go bid the Souldiers Shoot.
